text: <@UQBC76H2Q> I'm going for a wild guess here that this is an xy problem, and that you came from Matlab, and what you actually want is to use a `Vector` instead of a `Matrix`

elements.text: I'm going for a wild guess here that this is an xy problem, and that you came from Matlab, and what you actually want is to use a

text: Well, actually, this is the issue: No <@U0179G7FG4F>... sorry to say, that's not the case. So, I am using JuMP for optimization modeling. The dual variable corresponding to a constraint is output not as a plain Float64, but, as a 1x1 Array{Float64, 1}. Subsequently, I am trying to create a dataframe of those dual variabla values. Now, sometimes (depending on the user inputs) I can either have 1 constraint (this particular case), at other times, I can have multiple constraints, in which case, indeed it will be a column vector of dual variables.

elements.text: Well, actually, this is the issue: No

... sorry to say, that's not the case. So, I am using JuMP for optimization modeling. The dual variable corresponding to a constraint is output not as a plain Float64, but, as a 1x1 Array{Float64, 1}. Subsequently, I am trying to create a dataframe of those dual variabla values. Now, sometimes (depending on the user inputs) I can either have 1 constraint (this particular case), at other times, I can have multiple constraints, in which case, indeed it will be a column vector of dual variables.

text: makes sense. I took the guess because it happens a bunch to new users

text: While this might not at all be the case here, i'd say that it's often a case of scalar input -> scalar output, vector input -> vector output. Perhaps a @constraints was used where one should have used a @constraint

elements.text: While this might not at all be the case here, i'd say that it's often a case of scalar input -> scalar output, vector input -> vector output. Perhaps a @constraints was used where one should have used a @constraint

text: JuMP allows use of @constraint as well as @constraints. But, yeah, I agree with you <@U012XER8K4M>..... when it comes to dual variables, the current version of JuMP always vectorizes it, even if there's just one of it.
